Award.AwardTitle: CI-ADDO-NEW: Collaborative Research: Development of DARwIn Humanoid Robots for Research, Education and Outreach

Directorate.LongName: Direct For Computer & Info Scie & Enginr

Division.LongName: Division Of Computer and Network Systems

Award.AbstractNarration:
This project develops the DARwIn-miniature-humanoid-robot platform with advance computational power, sophisticated sensors, high payload capacity, and dynamic motion ability to enable many exciting research, education, and outreach activities. Two models of DARwIn robot, DARwIn-HP (High Performance) and DARwIn-LC (Low Cost), will be designed, fabricated, and built for distribution to 11 partner universities (including major research universities, RUI institutions, a women's college, and two local high schools) to establish a humanoid-robotics community. The project engages the humanoid-robotics community in a concerted effort to advance humanoid robotics.

The research results from the humanoid-robotics community will find applications in assistive robotics technology for the elderly, intelligent humanoids, and homeland security and the military. The partner universities will utilize DARwIn robots in their classroom teaching and projects as well as outreach activities to recruit high-school students and encourage them to select computer science or engineering for their career choices. An annual workshop will be organized and a website will be developed to broaden the DARwIn project and disseminate results. Public demonstrations of the robots at various high-impact events such as FIRST robotics competitions will capture the minds of K-12 students and promote interest in computer science and engineering among them.

POR.DRECONTENT:
This project has three major goals: 

  • To train students to develop humanoid robots in research and education
  • To use humanoid robots for raising the interests of K-12 students pursuing STEM career
  • To create relevant technologies useful in robotics research

This project has achieved these goals. Four humanoid robots are used at Purdue University for research and education.  This project has a focus on endowing the robots with the capability of understanding human­-human interactions.  The intellectual merit includes the development of techniques to determine where to best place sensors, to extract relevant features from sensed data (or more specifically, 3D point cloud), to model the relationship between human action and pose, and to estimate partially occluded human joint positions when two persons are interacting.  An online tool to facilitate research on computer vision has also been developed. This tool is called Continuous Analysis of Many Cameras (CAM2, https://cam2.ecn.purdue.edu/).

The broader impacts include the involvement of many K-12 and undergraduate students in this project.  An undergraduate student made a DARWIN-OP robot dance and it was highlighted in IEEE Spectrum (http://spectrum.ieee.org/automaton/robotics/diy/darwinop-learning-to-play-ddr). The Purdue team has worked with multiple outreach programs (such as Purdue's Women in Engineering Program and Purdue' Minority Engineering Program, as well as a local middle school) using humanoid robots to encourage middle and high school students to study STEM. Some of the activities are published in a paper in Frontier in Education 2010.

Many undergraduate students have participated in this project as developers for CAM2, an online tool for research on computer vision. This project allows researchers to execute vision programs analyzing data from thousands of network cameras. This project received an award in a student competition (Schurz Innovation Challenge, April 2014). More than 100 people outside Purdue have registered as users, further broadening the impacts of this project.
